content:
TRADE

US Commerce Secretary Ross said EU, Canada and Mexico will face steel and aluminium tariffs at midnight tonight with 25% tariff on steel and 10% on aluminium, while Ross also that there is no longer a precise date for NAFTA deadline. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker said tariffs are unacceptable and retaliatory measures will be installed within hours, while the EU is to also trigger dispute settlement case at WTO. (Newswires)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo announced it would be difficult to reach a NAFTA deal before the Mexican election following the US tariff decision but added that talks are still continuing. Guajardo also commented he does not expect a trade war after US tariffs on steel and aluminium and that tariffs affect USD 4bln of trade between Mexico and the US. (Newswires)

Canada PM Trudeau said he was told a five-year sunset clause was a pre-condition for a meeting with President Trump to finalise NAFTA. (Newswires)

UK Trade Minister Fox said the UK is not ruling out counter measures after the US imposed steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

Italy's Conte said M5S leader Di Maio to be Labour and Industry Minister and Deputy PM, League leader Salvini is to be Interior Minister and Deputy PM, while Tria was nominated as Finance Minister and Milanesi as Foreign Minister. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures reversed the overnight gains with downside seen as European traders got to their desks, and the Emini S&P futures started to slide as markets awaited US Commerce Secretary Ross announcements on tariffs. Following the announcement, the ES dropped, and despite positive developments in Italy, US trade partners announcing they would take counter measures kept risk assets on the defensive; however, the key 2700 level in ES held. In stock specifics: General Motors (GM) supported the SPX following a USD 2.2bln investment from Softbank into GM’s cruise self-driving unit, the stock saw intraday highs of close to 13%. Two names hampering the SPX today, Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) following weak earnings reports from both. SPX -0.66% at 2705, NDX -0.05% at 6972, DJI -1.01% at 24418.

Treasury futures were mixed on Thursday, though the general bias was towards lower yields, supported by trade war fears after the US slapped tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico. The complex saw a moderate sell off a bit later in the session after Italy agreed on a government deal but then paired back those losses as focus moved on Spain. Volume was thin in the front contract as open interest shifted into September contract. Most of the price action was concentrated in the belly and long ends of the curve, where yields were lower by c.1bps; 2s10s and 2s30s where narrower by c.3bps with the former at the flattest level in nearly 11 years. US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 45 ticks higher at 120-14.

US MARKET WRAP 31 May 2018: Trump’s tariffs worry markets, Italy’s government plan comes as reassurance
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, DXY flat, WTI mixed 
  • * REAR-VIEW: US slaps steel and aluminium tariffs on US, Canada, EU; Italy reached a government deal; DoE crude draw
  • * AHEAD: Spain government confidence vote; US nonfarm payrolls on Friday; Chinese Caixin PMIs overnight

 

*EUROPEAN POLITICS: The political situation in Italy stabilised on Thursday after the M5S and the League completed an accord on a coalition government. The two parties have chosen Conte for the PM position; an official reported the deal also sees Savona as the EU Affairs Minister, and academic Tria as the Finance Minister, Milanesi as Foreign Minister and La Stampa  reported Trenta as Defence Minister. M5S leader Di Maio will take the Industry Minister position and League's leader Salvini the Interior Minister role – both Salvini and Di Maio will reportedly take Deputy Premier roles, too. PM-designate Conte has confirmed these positions in later trade. After the reports, Italy’s previous PM-designate Cottarelli gave up on his mandate to form a government. ANSA suggested the new government will be sworn in on Friday afternoon, and a government confidence vote is to take place next Monday or Tuesday. Over in Spain, the Spanish opposition is seen close to securing votes necessary to remove current PM Rajoy, and the PP party said to most likely see a defeat in the no confidence vote on Friday. In later trade, Citizens party leader Rivera called on Rajoy to resign whilst PSOE’s Sanchez says he is willing to negotiate a date for Spanish election. Sources also reported Catalan lawmakers are to support the Socialists on a vote of no confidence.

*TRADE WARS: US Commerce Secretary Ross announced the EU, Canada and Mexico will face 25% tariff on steel and 10% on aluminium from midnight on Thursday. Ross explained that the decision was made for Canada and Mexico because the NAFTA negotiations took too long. In response, EU's Juncker said tariffs are unacceptable and retaliatory measure will be taken, with the EU triggering a dispute settlement case at the WTO. Mexico also responded and is to retaliate by imposing tariffs on flat steel, some pork and other foods with Mexico's Economy Minister Guajardo to publish tariff targets as soon as next week. He does not expect a trade war after US tariffs on steel and aluminium. UK Trade Minister Fox made clear the UK is not ruling out counter measures. German Chancellor Merkel said reciprocity is needed, adding any response to US tariffs must be smart and determined. Elsewhere, US President Trump told French President Macron that he would block German premium cars from entering the US market, according to German magazine Wirtschaftswoche. SAFE reported that China will actively expand imports. Earlier in the session, the Chinese finance ministry said to lower import tariffs on some consumer products from favoured nations as of July 1st, average tariff rate will fall to 6.9% from 15.7% on 1,449 products. Finally, Canada and Mexico will continue to negotiate with US on NAFTA. Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo announced it would be difficult to reach a NAFTA deal before the Mexican election, following the US tariff decision but does say talks are still continuing. Canada PM Trudeau added he was told a five-year sunset clause was a pre-condition for a meeting with President Trump to finalise NAFTA.

*GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump said there is ‘a very good chance’ a denuclearisation deal with North Korea will require more than one meeting, adding that it will cover missiles. US Secretary of State Pompeo said a lot of work remains to be done with North Korea, but he was positive; elsewhere, he avoided outlining what an agreement with North Korea might eventually look like.

*FED SPEAK: Fed's Brainard (voter, dovish)  expects US policy to be normalised gradually, and for the Fed to shift to a ‘modestly beyond neutral’ policy setting. She added the Fed needs to adjust ‘stale’ language around accommodative policy in its statement and she downplayed concerns of yield curve inversions. Elsewhere, above trend growth and stimulus calls for gradual hikes. Slack has diminished but there may be still some left. Brainard also dedicated some time towards events in Europe, saying financial conditions have deteriorated due to Italian political uncertainty; global financial market stress and possible channels to US are two important consideration for US monetary policy. Fed's Quarles (voter, neutral) said trade measures have not had a macro effect yet, and his near-term outlook has not changed. Fed’s Mester (voter, hawk) suggested rates should be raised gradually and noted Italy has not changed the view of economic fundamentals in the US. Wages are rising and that it will be reflected in data soon, but does not see inflation spiking higher.

*BOC SPEAK: BoC's Leduc repeated the BoC line that developments since April reinforce the view of higher interest rates to keep inflation on target and reiterated the BoC statement that trade policy uncertainty as a factor limiting business investment. He noted the economy is close to full potential, the labour market is improving and wages are rising. He favours a gradual approach to policy adjustments guided by data adding there is a lot of economic data to be seen before the July decision, and that the decisions are informed by data but the Q1 GDP reassures them that economy is travelling in the right direction. BoC’s Poloz said global growth was broad-based and synchronised.

*DATA: US personal consumption rose to 0.6%, in April above the 0.4% consensus. US Core PCE Price Index YY was inline at 1.80% whilst MM ticked slightly up at 0.2%. Capital Economics still anticipates PCE Inflation to rise above 2.0% in the incoming months which supports the Fed policy goal of at least three rate hikes this year, with the first hike coming in June. The strong consumption figures indicate a solid start to Q2, analysts said, though the cold weather dictated higher spending in energy and utility services. Some argue that gains are unlikely to be sustained as weather improves, with utility expected to drop sharply. Nonetheless, analysts at Pantheon see the Core PCE deflator hitting 2% in July and move further up in August. Elsewhere, Canada GDP moderated slightly in Q1 coming in at 1.3%, making a BoC July hike less certain, after this week’s upbeat policy statement. Looking at the components, household consumption rose by 1.1% whilst residential investment dropped by 7.2%. The housing market continued to weaken in April and looks unlikely to pick up as mortgage rates remain elevated. Similarly, uncertainty around NAFTA and the fresh tariffs imposed by the US will weigh on the economy, the BoC and analysts say. On the flip side, investment showed a 10.9% growth, flying in the face of some of those concerns. However, given that GDP has been slowing down for three consecutive quarters, it does not seem interest rates hike are necessary, analyst at Capital Economics said.

*EQUITIES: SPX -0.66% at 2705, NDX -0.05% at 6972, DJI -1.01% at 24418.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.47%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -1.65%, Energy: -0.75%, Financials: -0.69%, Health Care: -0.86%, Industrials: -1.24%, Materials: -0.67%, Telecom: -1.10%, Tech: +0.43%, Utilities: +0.18%

US equity futures traded higher overnight, following on from yesterday’s rebound where it consolidated around the recently watched 2730 level. There was downside as European traders got to their desks, and the Emini S&P futures started to slide as markets awaited US Commerce Secretary Ross announcements on tariffs. Following the announcement, the ES dropped, and despite positive developments in Italy, US trade partners announcing they would take counter measures kept risk assets on the defensive; however, the key 2700 level in ES held.

In stock specifics: General Motors (GM) supported the SPX following a USD 2.2bln investment from Softbank into GM’s cruise self-driving unit, the stock saw intraday highs of close to 13%. Two names hampering the SPX today, Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) following weak earnings reports from both.

*CRUDE: WTI futures settle down USD 1.17 at USD 67.04/bbl; Brent futures settle higher by USD 0.09 at USD 77.59/bbl. A cocktail of bearish factors engulfed the crude complex in early trade: the API data released on Wednesday showed a surprise build in inventories, the dollar strength was a headwind, unions in Brazil called for workers to cancel industrial action, and Shell restarted a platform in the Gulf of Mexico a full year ahead of schedule, Russia’s deputy oil minister said it could boost production levels by 300k BPD within months. Add to that a weak global risk narrative – after the US announced tariffs on Mexico, Canada and the EU, and European political risks remained in focus – and crude was offered as US traders got to their desks. There was some stabilisation around 67.00 in WTI. There was only a very limited uptick to crude prices after weekly DOE inventory data reported crude bullish/products bearish data: stocks drew down by a whopping 3.62mln barrels (exp. -0.5mln) in the week, Cushing stocks drew 556k barrels (Exp -1.123mln), gasoline built 534k (exp -1.368mlnm) and distillates built 634k (exp -1.25mln). However, US crude production continues to tick higher (+0.4% to 10.769mln BPD), keeping a lid on WTI upside. And after the 67.00 handle was given, lows below 66.50 were printed. Analysts at Citi also noted that on the Gulf Coast (PADD3) stocks dropped by 3.1mln, which suggests that fears that supply constraints may see builds in the Permian basin were pushed back.

*FIXED INCOME: US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 45 ticks higher at 120-14. Treasury futures were mixed on Thursday, though the general bias was towards lower yields, supported by trade war fears after the US slapped tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico. The complex saw a moderate sell off a bit later in the session after Italy agreed on a government deal but then paired back those losses as focus moved on Spain. Volume was thin in the front contract as open interest shifted into September contract. Most of the price action was concentrated in the belly and long ends of the curve, where yields were lower by c.1bps; 2s10s and 2s30s where narrower by c.3bps with the former at the flattest level in nearly 11 years.

*FOREX:  USD: A turnaround in overall risk sentiment and the Greenback’s fortunes as a result, with losses pared and/or reversed in wake of the imposition of aluminium and steel taxes vs the EU, Canada and Mexico, with almost immediate effect. The DXY duly bounced from sub-94.000 lows as Dollar/Major and EMs especially reversed course.

CAD: Literally from hero to zero for the Loonie as considerably weaker than forecast Canadian GDP (annualised y/y measure) undermined and belied the BoC’s more upbeat post-policy meeting growth assessment yesterday, and the US also raised the bar for a NAFTA deal by declaring no end date for negotiations. USDCAD rebounded sharply to circa 1.2975 from just above 1.2800 as a result, and consolidated around just above 1.2950, while USDMXN tested 20.000 as the PESO also felt the full force of US tariff angst, and Mexico announced retaliatory action.

JPY, CHF: Both back in demand on safe-haven grounds as global trade war tensions ramped up again in early trade, with USDJPY pulling back further from 109.00, while the Franc tested 0.9850 and above 1.1500 vs the Eur. There was some deflation in the haven bid after positive news on the Italian front.

NZD, AUD: Resilient in the face of the USD recovery, with the Kiwi clinging on to the 0.7000 handle on favourable cross winds as Aud/Usd remained capped by 0.7600 and hefty option expiry interest above ahead of the NY cut, and Aud/Nzd stayed close to 1.0800. AUD struggled to keep up with the Kiwi;s pace after weak CAPEX data overnight.

EUR, GBP: Ended the Thursday’s EU session narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, but the single currency well off 1.1700+ peaks on firmer and essentially in line with ECB target Eurozone inflation plus less political angst on the Italian front. EURUSD is back below its 10 DMA (1.1690) and tested support around 1.1650 as negotiations in Rome continued, but there was upside following positive developments in Italy, though the 1.17 level remained a struggle ahead of tomorrow’s confidence vote in Spain. Cable relatively resilient around 1.3300, albeit down from peaks near 1.3350.

*COMING-UP: US nonfarm payrolls data will be released at 1330 BST/0830 EDT on 1 June 2018. Non-farm Payrolls: (Exp. 188k, Prev. 164k). Last month, the US added 164k nonfarm payrolls, easing from the recent average pace; over the last 6-months, payroll growth has averaged 198k, slightly firmer than the 12-month pace of 190k. The 3-month average has been easing over the last quarter, and is currently running at a clip of 208k. For full preview click here.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY regroups as US rolls out tariffs
content:
USD

A turnaround in overall risk sentiment and the Greenback’s fortunes as a result, with losses pared and/or reversed in wake of the imposition of aluminium and steel taxes vs the EU, Canada and Mexico, with almost immediate effect. The DXY duly bounced from sub-94.000 lows as Dollar/Major and EMs especially reversed course.

CAD

Literally from hero to zero for the Loonie as considerably weaker than forecast Canadian GDP (annualised y/y measure) undermined and belied the BoC’s more upbeat post-policy meeting growth assessment yesterday, and the US also raised the bar for a NAFTA deal by declaring no end date for negotiations. Usd/Cad rebounded sharply to circa 1.2975 from just above 1.2800 as a result, and almost back to Wednesday’s pre-BoC levels, while Usd/Mxn tested 20.000 as the PESO also felt the full force of US tariff angst, and Mexico announced retaliatory action.

JPY/CHF

Both back in demand on safe-haven grounds as global trade war tensions ramped up again, with Usd/Jpy pulling back further from 109.00 and below 108.50, while the Franc tested 0.9850 and retreated through 1.1500 vs the Eur.

NZD/AUD

Resilient in the face of the Usd recovery, with the Kiwi clinging on to the 0.7000 handle on favourable cross winds as Aud/Usd remained capped by 0.7600 and hefty option expiry interest above ahead of the NY cut, and Aud/Nzd stayed close to 1.0800.

EUR/GBP  

Ending Thursday’s EU session narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, but the single currency well off 1.1700+ peaks on firmer and essentially in line with ECB target Eurozone inflation plus less political angst on the Italian front. Eur/Usd is back below its 10 DMA (1.1690) and tested support around 1.1650 as negotiations in Rome continue and the countdown to Madrid’s ‘si’ or ‘no’ to PM Rajoy ticks down. Cable relatively resilient around 1.3300, albeit down from peaks near 1.3350.

content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • BTPs recovering as tensions calm in Italy, with talks set to resume later in the day; EZ CPI provides no shocks
  • Focus set on Spanish no-confidence debate, as Cuidadanos ahead in polls and PP collapses to 4th
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US personal consumption and PCE price index, Chicago PMI, Canadian GDP and DoEs

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian markets traded positive across the board as the regional bourses follow suit from the rebound seen in their global counterparts after political fears surrounding Italy subsided, while participants also digested strong Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by the energy sector following similar outperformance on Wall St after source reports suggested OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was also positive but with gains initially contained after a pullback in USD/JPY and miss on Industrial Production data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) conformed to the positivity with outperformance in mainland China after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMIs in which the former data release printed an 8-month high. In addition, officials also did their part to help out with China to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods and will announce a new negative list which would ease investment restrictions on certain sectors, while the PBoC conducted a substantial daily net liquidity injection of CNY 180bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar subdued performance in T-Notes, due to a broad recovery in risk sentiment and after weaker demand in today’s 2yr JGB auction.

China Mofcom said China is not willing to see an escalation in trade tensions with US, while it added that the measures against China are against WTO rules and that China reserves the right to respond with countermeasures. In other news, China Mofcom said that China will release a new negative list on foreign investment by June 30th at the latest, which will include measures to relax or drop restrictions on sectors including energy, resources and transportation. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (May) 51.9 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4); highest since September. (Newswires)

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (May) 54.9 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.8)

Chinese Composite PMI (May) 54.6 (Prev. 54.1)

PBoC injected CNY 90bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 60bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 70bln via 28-day reverse repos, for a net daily injection of CNY 180bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4144 (Prev. 6.4207)

EU/UK/US

EU Unemployment Rate (Apr) 8.5% vs. Exp. 8.4% (Prev. 8.5%, Rev. 8.6%)

EU CPI Flash YY (May) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.2%)

EU CPI ex Food & Energy Flash YY (May) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.1%)

EU CPI ex Food, Energy, Alcohol & Tobacco Flash YY (May) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%)

The debate over the vote of no confidence is Spain has begun its debate, with Sanchez stating he will maintain the PPs budgetary plans should they come in to power. Spain's Cuidadanos is leading opinion polls at 28.6%, PP in 4th at 19.6% place (Newswires)

Should the Cottarelli government fail, Savona could be considered for Foreign minister in a League/5SM government, Angelo Ciocca a possible pick for finance minister. Italy's League and Brothers of Italy are however quoted to join forces at the potential upcoming elections, 5SM are also open to a Brothers of Italy coalition. This is amid Italy League leader Salvini cancelling all his rallies today to return to Rome. 5SM's Di Maio and League's Salvini may meet today for government talks; according to an official. Should the talks between 5SM and League fail, Cottarelli could be sworn in as early as today. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Jonathan Haskel has been nominated to the BoE's MPC by the Treasury replacing hawkish McCafferty. (Newswires)

SNB's Zurbrugg says current monetary policy takes into account of fragility in FX markets. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump is to impose metal tariffs on Canada, Mexico and EU, according to reports in Washington Post. US Commerce Secretary Ross says that US steel and aluminium tariffs on EU are to be announced before markets open or after markets close today; adding that US does not want a trade war. (Newswires)

US President Trump has told French President Macron that he would block German premium cars from entering the US market. (Wirtschaftswoche)

EQUITIES

European stocks (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%) are largely tracking higher as the tension surrounding Italian politics cools further. The underperforming bourse is the DAX (-0.4%) which is being weighed upon by a possible US import ban on German autos. Large index constituents Daimler (-1.0%), Volkswagen (-1.9%) and BMW (-0.5%) all negative on the day.

Spanish banks are seeing positivity as the no confidence vote debate in Spain begins (Santander +1.2% and Banco Bilbao +1.4%), with expectations set on the ousting of Spanish PM Rajoy.

Firstgroup collapsing to the bottom of the Stoxx 600 (-14.5%) after the resignation of their CEO.

FX

DXY

The Greenback is weaker across the board again, and partly due to gains in rival currencies, but also as simmering tit-for-tat tariff threats have resurfaced hot on the heels of yesterday’s mainly sub-forecast US data. Hence, the index has pulled back further from 2018 peaks just above 95.000 to 93.710, while EMs continue their recovery or at least consolidate off all time/multi-year lows.

EUR

Back to best G10 performer on more stronger than expected Eurozone inflation data (French, Italian and the pan print), and another downturn in investor concerns regarding the political stalemate in Rome. The single currency has cleared another big figure at 1.1700 and its 10 DMA (1.1690) on the way up to a circa 1.1725 peak, but may now get bogged down by hefty option expiries spanning 1.1700-50.

GBP

Technicals rather than fundamentals appear to be behind the Pound’s revival vs the Usd as Cable reclaims 1.3300+ status, but lags the Eur with the cross approaching 0.8800.

CAD/CHF

Both around 0.2-0.25% up vs the Usd, with the Loonie extending post-BoC gains to 1.2835 and now looking for Canadian GDP data to back up the Central Bank’s more upbeat economic assessment. The Franc has climbed a bit further vs the Usd to around 0.9870, but like Sterling has not kept pace with the Eur after latest SNB comments underlining that the current monetary policy stance is apt for choppy currency market conditions. Note, not much net response to a Swiss retail sales beat or a mixed GDP release.

NZD/AUD

Pretty much neck-and-neck for the antipodean dollars as the cross nestles in a 1.0820-60 range and both recover losses seen overnight on more disappointing macro news in the form of NZ business sentiment and Ausie capex. The Kiwi is back near 0.7000 and Aud almost as close to its nearest round number circa 0.7590, but perhaps capped by big expiries just above (0.7600-05 in 2 bn).

JPY

Still stuck in a narrow band vs the Usd just under 109.00, after much weaker than anticipated Japanese IP data and amidst more decent option interest between 108.90-109.00 (1.1 bn).

FIXED INCOME

More choppy trade in debt markets, but Italian bonds did complete their recovery from Tuesday’s lows to trade just above 129.00, and alongside confirmation of a significantly above consensus pan-Eurozone inflation update Bunds hit a fresh Eurex base of 160.95 (-107 ticks). Meanwhile, Gilts continue to pretty much track Bunds and slipped to 122.80 (-63 ticks) before retesting 123.00 and US Treasuries are mid-range from overnight session highs to lows awaiting a raft of data to end the month that has a relatively long index extension. Inflation will also be a major focus with the Fed’s preferred price measure in the form of core PCE due alongside another NFP proxy via weekly claims.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are trading mixed today with Brent (-0.6%) and WTI (-0.4%) gradually extending losses on the day following the latest API crude inventory printing a surprise build in headline crude stockpiles. Note we will see the release of the weekly DoE’s today due to the US Memorial Day on Monday.

Elsewhere, Gold (+0.2%) trades marginally higher as it tracks the greenback following the uneventful Asia-Pac session. Meanwhile, base metals (with the exception of copper) were boosted by a strong Chinese manufacturing PMI reading with Shanghai nickel soaring to fresh three-year highs and London zinc higher by 0.8%. 

On the trade front, US Secretary Wilbur Ross said that US steel and aluminium tariffs on EU will be announced as early as today, before US markets open or after markets close.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (25 May) 1.001M vs. Exp. -0.500M (Prev. -1.300M). (Newswires)

content: A somewhat belated decline along the Short Sterling strip that seemed to defy gravity and external leads on Wednesday, but Gilts are behaving or conforming to the negative tone in counterpart core fixed largely on less Italian BTP selling and another short squeeze. Independent or UK-specific drivers remain thin on the ground, and mixed at best, so it’s follow moves elsewhere unless upcoming data surprises or something Brexit-related emerges. Back to Liffe, 3 month futures are down 5 ticks at the low end, while the 10 year bond has been as much as 55 ticks below yesterday’s settlement at 122.88, as Bunds extend their retreat to 161.18 for an 84 tick drop on the day.

content: Softer US Treasury leads and broadly positive risk sentiment courtesy of upbeat Chinese PMIs have pushed core bonds down further from recent peaks, but for Bunds and fellow Eurozone safe-haven debt futures it’s mainly a function of more unwinding on the back of an ongoing recovery BTPs/peripheral paper. The 10 year German benchmark has been down to 161.37 vs yesterday’s 162.02 Eurex close, while its Italian equivalent spiked to 127.36 from 124.84 at one stage. Back to macro impulses, another stronger than forecast national CPI print, via France, will also be fodder for fixed bears ahead of the pan Eurozone release, which clearly has an upside bias vs consensus and could fuel expectations that the ECB will deliver a hawkish tweak to forward guidance in June.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

31st May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian markets traded positive across the board as the regional bourses follow suit from the rebound seen in their global counterparts after political fears surrounding Italy subsided, while participants also digested strong Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by the energy sector following similar outperformance on Wall St after source reports suggested OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was also positive but with gains initially contained after a pullback in USD/JPY and miss on Industrial Production data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) conformed to the positivity with outperformance in mainland China after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMIs in which the former data release printed an 8-month high. In addition, officials also did their part to help out with China to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods and will announce a new negative list which would ease investment restrictions on certain sectors, while the PBoC conducted a substantial daily net liquidity injection of CNY 180bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar subdued performance in T-Notes, due to a broad recovery in risk sentiment and after weaker demand in today’s 2yr JGB auction.

FTSE

EX-DIVS: Marks & Spencer (MKS LN), National Grid (NG/ LN), Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 6 points off the FTSE 100

RBS (RBS LN) – The British Government has rejected a proposal to give investors more of a say over pay at the bank. (FT)

WPP (WPP LN) – Proxy adviser ISS has lent their support to executive chairman Quarta by recommending him for re-election at WPP’s AGM. (Newswires)

HSBC (HSBA LN) / RBS (RBS LN) – HSBC has interviewed ex-RBS CFO Stevenson for the finance director position. (Times)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

(FT)

US

*EQUITIES: SPX 1.27% at 2724, NDX +0.72% at 6976, DJI +1.26% at 24668.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.83%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +1.38%, Energy: +3.01%, Financials: +1.82%, Health Care: +1.36%, Industrials: +1.24%, Materials: +1.15%, Telecom: +0.74%, Tech: %, Utilities: +0.69%

US Equity futures rebounded from yesterday’s sell-off, which many analysts believed to be overdone; UBS noted that S&P500 revenue exposure to Europe and Italy is only about 10% and 1% respectively, so overall the impact of the political woes in Italy to US equities is likely to be minimal. The Emini S&P 500 grinded higher overnight before being boosted at the US cash open and breaking back above the 100dma at 2712, (which was breached to the downside yesterday), and then finding resistance with the familiar 2730 level.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 31st May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities higher after following suit from the rebound seen in their global counterparts as Italian fears subside (for now) and encouraging Chinese data
  • Italy's Five Star Movement have called for Savona to withdraw candidacy for Economy Minister to allow a government to be formed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone CPI, US personal consumption and PCE price index, Chicago PMI, Canadian GDP and DoEs

 

ASIA

Asian markets traded positive across the board as the regional bourses follow suit from the rebound seen in their global counterparts after political fears surrounding Italy subsided, while participants also digested strong Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by the energy sector following similar outperformance on Wall St after source reports suggested OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was also positive but with gains initially contained after a pullback in USD/JPY and miss on Industrial Production data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) conformed to the positivity with outperformance in mainland China after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMIs in which the former data release printed an 8-month high. In addition, officials also did their part to help out with China to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods and will announce a new negative list which would ease investment restrictions on certain sectors, while the PBoC conducted a substantial daily net liquidity injection of CNY 180bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar subdued performance in T-Notes, due to a broad recovery in risk sentiment and after weaker demand in today’s 2yr JGB auction.

China Mofcom said China is not willing to see an escalation in trade tensions with US, while it added that the measures against China are against WTO rules and that China reserves the right to respond with countermeasures. In other news, China Mofcom said that China will release a new negative list on foreign investment by June 30th at the latest, which will include measures to relax or drop restrictions on sectors including energy, resources and transportation. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (May) 51.9 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4); highest since September. (Newswires)
Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (May) 54.9 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 54.8)
Chinese Composite PMI (May) 54.6 (Prev. 54.1)

PBoC injected CNY 90bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 60bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 70bln via 28-day reverse repos, for a net daily injection of CNY 180bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4144 (Prev. 6.4207)


UK/EU

UK PM May has been told by the leaders of some of Europe's biggest companies that "clarity and certainty" is needed over Brexit because "time is running out". (Sky News)

Former UK cabinet members Amber Rudd, Damian Green and Justine Greening held a private meeting with PM May yesterday at which they informed her that there was a large majority in the parliamentary party in favour of a compromise with the EU.

France is reported to be blocking UK plan for a post-Brexit security agreement. (The Sun)
 

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (May) -7 vs. Exp. -8 (Prev. -9). (Newswires)
UK Lloyds Business Barometer (May) 35 (Prev. 32)

Italy's President Mattarella and PM-designate Cottarelli agreed not to rush the situation to see if a political government can be formed, according to a source close to the President. (Newswires)

Italy's Five Star Movement have called for Savona to withdraw candidacy for Economy Minister to allow a government to be formed, while party leader Di Maio said Savona should be part of M5S-League government but not as Economy Minister. Di Maio also noted that an alternative Economy Minister should try to renegotiate treaties in the EU if the League agrees and that the choice is either a snap election or a political government. (Newswires)

The Spanish opposition is seen close to securing votes necessary to remove current PM Rajoy. while his PP party is said to most likely see a defeat in the no confidence vote on Friday. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, USD remained softer following the prior day’s declines with the DXY-index in close proximity of the 94.00 level to the benefit of its major counterparts. As such, EUR/USD held on to the majority of its recent advances and GBP/USD reclaimed the 1.3300 handle, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD pared some of the gains as weaker than expected Australian private capex data and softer New Zealand business surveys slightly dampened. Elsewhere, the greenback’s NAFTA peers were mixed with CAD firm following the more hawkish tilt by the BoC in its policy statement and with MXN weighed by reports that US President Trump is to proceed on metal tariffs on Canada, Mexico and EU which could be announced later today.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were quiet overnight in which WTI crude futures traded relatively sideways as prices took a breather from the prior days advances after source reports dampened prospects of a significant lift in output by OPEC+, while the latest API crude inventory data also failed to spur any significant market reaction despite a surprise build in headline crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold was relatively flat as the opposing forces from the risk-sentiment and dollar-dynamics continue to counterbalance, while copper conformed to the uneventful overnight trade observed across the complex. 

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (25 May) 1.001M vs. Exp. -0.500M (Prev. -1.300M). (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh called for OPEC to support Iran in its coming struggle with the US sanctions defining them 'illegal, unilateral, extraterritorial', while he demanded to place the US sanctions topic on the agenda at its next meeting on June 22nd. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

White House Press Secretary Sanders said the US continues to prepare for the 12th June North Korea summit and that preparations have been positive so far. In related news, North Korea's Yongbyon nuclear research complex is said to still be active, while there were also reports that Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov arrived in North Korea. (Newswires/KCNA)

North Korean leader’s right-hand man Kim Yong-chol met with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in New York to discuss next steps of summit. Pompeo then tweeted he had a “good working dinner” with the North Korean official. He is the most senior North Korean to visit the US in almost two decades. (BBC)

US

Treasuries edged lower on Wednesday as equities steadied and oil rebounded amid easing political concerns over in Europe, yet no government has been formed in Italy. Some analysts were noting that volume was elevated across the curve as attention shifted to the September contracts (June contracts expires on 20th June). Most of the action was concentrated on the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were higher by c.1bps. Although yields were higher, modest flattening was seen across the yield curve. However, 2s30s and 5s30s narrowed by c.5bps and 2s10s and 5s10s narrowed by c.5bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 20 ticks lower at 120-19+.

US President Trump is to impose metal tariffs on Canada, Mexico and EU, with an announcement expected as soon as today. (Washington Post) Such a move is likely to bring retaliatory actions from EU trade regulators. (WSJ)

Fed Beige Book stated the US economy expanded moderately in late April and beginning of May with few shifts in growth pattern and that manufacturing moved into 'higher gear' with more than half of Fed districts reporting a pickup in industrial activity. Furthermore, it added that employment increased at modest/moderate rate and that price and wage increases were modest. (Newswires)

US Federal Reserve and financial regulators have revealed proposals to ease the Volcker Rule which bans banks from prop trading. (Newswires)

Trump Lawyer Giuliani said the President is working on Q&A preparation for the Mueller investigation. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Easing of political fears and strong Chinese PMI data inspired a rebound in Asia
content: Asia markets traded positive across the board as the regional bourses follow suit to the rebound seen in their global counterparts after political fears surrounding Italy subsided, while participants also digested strong Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by the energy sector following similar outperformance on Wall St after source reports suggested OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was also positive but with gains initially contained after a pullback in USD/JPY and miss on Industrial Production data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.4%) conformed to the positivity with outperformance in mainland China after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMIs in which the former data release printed an 8-month high. In addition, officials also did their part to help out with China to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods and will announce a new negative list which would ease investment restrictions on certain sectors, while the PBoC conducted a substantial daily net liquidity injection of CNY 180bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre amid a similar subdued performance in T-Notes, due to a broad recovery in risk sentiment and after weaker demand in today’s 2yr JGB auction.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Easing of political fears and strong Chinese PMI data inspires a rebound in Asia
content:
Asia markets trade positive across the board as the regional bourses follow suit to the rebound seen in their global counterparts after political fears surrounding Italy subsided, while participants also digest encouraging Chinese PMI data. ASX 200 (+0.5%) is led higher by the energy sector following similar outperformance on Wall St after oil prices were underpinned by source reports which suggested that OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) is also positive but with gains slightly moderating after a pullback in USD/JPY and miss on Industrial Production data. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) conform to the positivity with mainland China outperforming after better than expected Chinese Official Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMIs in which the former data release printed an 8-month high. In addition, officials also did their part to help out with reports stating that China is to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods, while the PBoC conducted a substantial daily net liquidity injection of CNY 180bln.

In FX markets, USD remains softer following the prior day’s declines with the DXY-index approaching closer towards the 94.00 level to the benefit of its major counterparts. As such, EUR/USD holds on to the majority of its recent advances and GBP/USD attempts a reclaim of the 1.3300 handle, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD have pared some of the gains as weaker than expected Australian private capex data and softer New Zealand business surveys slightly dampen. Elsewhere, the greenback’s NAFTA peers are mixed with CAD firm following the more hawkish tilt by the BoC in its policy statement and with MXN weighed by reports that US President Trump is to proceed on metal tariffs on Canada, Mexico and EU which could be announced later today.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lacklustre amid a similar subdued performance in T-Notes as demand is sapped by a broad recovery in risk sentiment and with participants awaiting a 2yr auction later.
